content.description: One of the very few chimneys in Humboldt. Unfortunately it's pretty mossy. I was surprised the moss didn't really get in the way, and the movement is very enjoyable.
content.protection: Gear, kind-of. Either finish at the tree or at the Henchman anchors.

content.description: 5.7 warm up that's not too bad. Stay below the bolts and head up and right on the ramp. Easy way to set up a top rope for the 5.10b, but you will still need someone to follow to clean.
content.location: Shares same useless bolt at the start of Case Dismissed and traverses out right to the anchor of Hibachi.

content.description:
A fun and wacky route that can be finished via either Cherry Picker or The Henchman. Layback or offwidth up to a roof. First thing you'll notice at the roof is that there are no holds. Find a very hidden right hand sidepull and do a deadpoint to hand jam deep in the hole under the lip of the roof. One more hand jam over the lip gets you to your next clip. Above the lip, traverse left then merge with Cherry Picker or the Henchman. The Cherry Picker finish is steeper, harder, but a classic. The Henchman finish is easier but has a slight runnout above the 6th bolt on 5.10a (optional small cam).

The climb had a lot of loose rock that was cleaned off. It still passes some spooky, hollow rock that is actually very solid and doesn't budge, even by mechanical means. Longer draws or slings are needed because the bolts needed to go in the best rock, which wasn't always the straightest line.

Clipping them all with standard draws would probably lead to some pretty horrendous drag. I clipped the two bolts under the first roof medium length (12"), and clipped the next two bolts afterward the first roof long (24").
content.location: Line of tan bolts to the left of the chimney.

content.description:
Start in the left facing slab dihedral of The Hencheman, then continue up the dihedral as it transitions to a right facing overhang. The gear is mostly small, but pretty good throughout the route. After a fun layback section, bust out left into the upper headwall with two fixed draws. Save a .75 or #1 for the finish! Anchor to the right.

The geometry of this climb is pretty fantastic!
content.protection: Gear .1-1" and two fixed draws. Extra .5-.75 is nice.
content.location: left facing dihedral that transitions to right facing.

content.description: Left start variation to Happy Trails that meets up at the 4th bolt. Start on the arete and traverse right on the path of least resistance which, no coincidence is right below the bolts. Hard cross overs with burly climbing and difficult beta on overhung rock changes to moderate climbing as it merges with Happy Trails.
content.protection:
11 bolts, 2 fixed draws. Lower off biners

Clip the fourth bolt long to easily back-clean it.
content.location: Farthest left route on the main face of the Glory Hole

content.description:
This thing is weird! Don’t expect any semblance of “normal” climbing.

Stemming turns weird as the slab dihedral steepens into a roof dihedral. Tricky right arm stemming and pushing moves are required to exit the roof. Your ability to think in 3D with dictate how long you spend in the roof. Get creative!

After the first roof, there is a good rest followed by a second roof out right. Going left looks easier, but is harder and risks a ledge fall. Go right, straight above your bolt. Stem and a massive jug awaits you above the roof. The route finishes with 40' of moderate climbing.

If you pay attention to the bolt line, and extend certain clips appropriately (12" draws on some, and 24" slings on others), the rope will run nearly perfectly straight with no rope drag. I haven't tested clipping them all with standard draws, but I imagine it would be a nightmare.
content.protection:
11 clips, three are fixed draws now. The two bolts just after the first two fixed draws must be clipped with a sling.

Double chain anchor, clip the correct chains that equalize for this route.
content.location: Nearest route to the trunk of the live tree.

content.description: Mostly bolted route with a few necessary gear placements. Stick clip the first bolt and work your way up a dihedral with gear towards a thin vertical face followed by a bulge. An optional small/medium cam can be also placed before the anchors.
content.protection: Stick clip, bolts, and gear .4-.5” and optional #1
content.location: starts on the right hand side of the downed log.

content.description: Dihedral start followed by steeper section with jugs out right around the corner. Crux comes with a very hard-to-decipher sequence moving left at the 4th bolt with a left hand gaston and good footwork. Definitely not the greatest route on its own, but it is a decent warmup for the many 5.11s on the wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts, chain anchor with lower off biners
content.location: Farthest right route on the wall

content.description: The Henchman is a rising traverse of the main face of the Glory Hole from left to right. It begins with some tricky and very thoughtful moves protected by gear. I used an OK-ish offset cam followed by a #1 nut near the start (left semi-fixed), then good gear after that after a few committing moves. Moving between the 11d and 11c bolt line is a little tricky, and a fall clipping the second bolt would be bad news, but the moves are all there. After that, the route is mellow passing two more bolts before the anchor (clip them long).
content.protection: Four bolts. Gear up to .75, slings. Rap rings
content.location: Blocky dihedral start 23' left of the 11d.

content.description:
This incredible roof prow lies between both overhanging 5.11 dihedrals.

Climb leftward from the start of Mineshaft to a high first bolt. Some 5.11+ climbing leads to a kneebar where you can pre-clip the roof. Thrutchy moves on good holds lead to a wild turn-around and bat hang exit the roof. Weather you want it or not, the bat hang, is by far the "easy" way. Try it! The challenges continue with a tricky sequence to pull the lip with a right heel hook. Once on the ledge, run it out 15' up the grungy dihedral to two bolts in a bulge (surprise techical difficulties). Pull the bulge and merge in with the last three bolts of Anonymous Tip.
content.protection: 12 bolts, 4 are fixed draws. Bring some slings and longer draws for the upper half.
content.location: Obvious roof/prow with fixed draws on the left side of the wall.

content.description:
Yet another great route on the Glory Hole featuring funky holds and awesome movement. It may look easier to start left of the bolts in the junky looking rock, but there are no good holds over there, follow the bolt line directly on yellow rock for the best holds. Throw for a hidden incut jug right of the first bolt and work your way up more sneaky jugs. Work your way past a few more small roofs for another 50' and find yourself a the base of the well protected but very overhanging finish.

The biggest challenge for most folks is just finding the correct holds. It starts to feel much easier after you've figured out where they are. Great mental challenge.
content.protection: 11 bolts, two fixed draws. Lower off biners.
content.location: 25' right of the left arete. Metoleous enviro-hangers.

content.description:
The first thing you'll notice as you pull onto Devil's Dominion is just how cryptic the sequences are. At first, most of the route feels just downright impossible, but as you work out the incredibly unique sequences it starts to come together as a masterpiece of a route!

Climb up and right on some good holds, then enter the first crux (V8) with a large reach to an undercling with an absurdly high foot, karate chop your right hand to match the undercling, magically stand up into a second undercling, transition your left to a third undercling-gaston, and jam the crack. Rest on the mono then pull through the second crux (V5) with big moves and big compression. Rest on the ledge and enter the final crux, the 25' V7+ crux of Dance With The Devil.
content.protection:
13 bolts, 6 are fixed draws.

Stick clip the first two bolts with 24" slings.
content.location: Start in the overhang above the cool downed tree. Belay down below the tree.

content.description:
This is one sweet route. Once you figure out the sequences, you won't forget it! It begins with The Henchman's gear start and continues up and left through an incredible overhang (V7+) and then finishes with 40' of 5.8-5.9 with a little wake-up just before the anchors. Very tricky beta, tenuous yet delicate power moves, did I mention tricky beta? If it feels impossible just keep working on those sequences .

The roof has fixed draws placed close enough to keep you plenty safe. There is a direct, harder start below named "Devil's Dominion."
content.protection:
Gear .2-.75, four fixed draws, 5-6 draws

There should be a semi-fixed #1 nut for convenience.
content.location: Starts at the left end of the downed log.

content.description: A short route, but still very fun with a nice crux. Boulder up to a ledge and walk/climb right 15' to the base of the roof. Cool climbing with some undercling jugs and tricky feet through the overhang. The bolts will lead you primarily though the yellow rock.
content.protection: Five bolts, one is fixed draw. Lower off biners on top.
content.location: Obvious steep bulge on the far left of the Glory Hole. Begin 20 feet left of the major arete.

content.description:
This is a direct straight-up link up between The Henchman and Mineshaft utilizing three bolts on some steep new terrain.

After the gear start, step left into the steep obtuse corner. Tricky sequence here that leads to a throw to a big edge at the second bolt. Move right and find the undercling and throw again past the next bolt, then just crank crimps to your fourth bolt (which clearly needs to be clipped with a sling). Finish up on Mineshaft.
content.protection:
Gear: micro nuts and cams .3-1”.

9 bolts. Bring slings.
content.location: Starts in the obtuse gear protected dihedral of The Henchman, then heads slightly left before heading straight up.

content.description: One of the very best routes at LOTL and one of the best 5.11s in Humboldt. Great rock, great sequences and plenty of sustained climbing all finished with a sweet overhang at the top. The start has become a bit harder than the original 11c grade with some rock breakage, 11d may be more accurate now. Stick clip needed.
content.location: Now the second route left of the big chimney.

content.description: Crimps, sidepulls, and the occasional hidden jug.  Crux is about halfway up.  Still a little bit of loose rock on this one.
content.location: Furthest right bolted route at the Glory Hole.

content.description: A tricky sequence around the second bolt lead to great jugs before a crux with two fixed draws. The fixed draws ensure solid clipping stances and make sure the bolts are where they need to be to keep the rope running clean. The crux sequence is criptic; relaxing when you've figured it out but frustrating when you haven't. The crux falls are all air and on fixed draws, so get on it. After the crux, you can rest on a the tip of a big rock protruding out from the wall. The remaining 40' of 5.9-5.10a is no gimmie. This route is tricky, but definitely less weird that Mineshaft. Depending on your climbing style, you may find the grades reversed.
